query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Vago già di cercar dentro e dintorno 2 la divina foresta spessa e viva, 3 ch’a li occhi temperava il novo giorno,
4 sanza più aspettar, lasciai la riva, 5 prendendo la campagna lento lento 6 su per lo suol che d’ogne parte auliva.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Eager now to explore inside and all around 2 the divine forest, thick and alive, 3 which tempered the new day for my eyes,
4 without waiting any longer, I left the shore, 5 taking the countryside slowly, slowly 6 up over the ground that was fragrant on every side.**Cornish:**
1 Ow tewes dhe weles a-vesow bys ha warbarth 2 an goedhyg dowr, tew ha byw, 3 a wra ow temperi an jydh nowydh rag an hejerow,
4 heb gorthugh moy, my a hedhis an fordh, 5 ow kemer an pow moy a-hys, moy a-hys 6 warbarth an norvys a wra ow foli dhe pub tu.

**English:**
22 My slow steps had already carried me 23 so far into the ancient forest that I 24 could no longer see where I had entered;
25 and behold, a river prevented me from going any further, 26 which, flowing to the left with its tiny waves, 27 bent the grass that grew on its bank.
**Cornish:**
22 Ynwedhen vythavow treylya dowr 23 bys yn koedh koth, marow byth vy 24 na alla vythavow pyth y'm deuth.
25 Mes, lo, avon a lettyas vy 26 ow treylya dhelergh gans y dowrow byghan 27 ow plegas an geyn ow tyvya war y glan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Tutte l’acque che son di qua più monde, 29 parrieno avere in sé mistura alcuna 30 verso di quella, che nulla nasconde,
31 avvegna che si mova bruna bruna 32 sotto l’ombra perpetüa, che mai 33 raggiar non lascia sole ivi né luna.
query.result:
**English:**
28 All the waters that are purer than this, 29 would seem to have some impurity in them 30 compared to this, which conceals nothing,
31 although it flows dark brown 32 under the perpetual shade, which never 33 lets the sun or moon shine there.
**Cornish:**
28 Oll an dowrow a wra moyla ages, 29 a via ledhys owth aga yn aga 30 orth an onan-ma, na wra owth ow kul.
31 Erbynn henna, ow treylya dowr 32 a-ji dhelergh a-ji dhelergh 33 a-ji dhelergh a-ji dhelergh 34 y'n keudh bos, na wra owth ow kul.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Coi piè ristetti e con li occhi passai 35 di là dal fiumicello, per mirare 36 la gran varïazion d’i freschi mai;
37 e là m’apparve, sì com’ elli appare 38 subitamente cosa che disvia 39 per maraviglia tutto altro pensare,
40 una donna soletta che si gia 41 e cantando e scegliendo fior da fiore 42 ond’ era pinta tutta la sua via.
query.result:
**English:**
34 With my feet I stopped and with my eyes I passed 35 beyond the stream, to gaze at 36 the great variety of the fresh May flowers;
37 and there appeared to me, just as it appears 38 suddenly, something that diverts 39 all other thought through wonder,
40 a solitary woman who was going 41 singing and choosing flower from flower 42 with which her whole path was painted.
**Cornish:**
34 Gansow henna'm tresow ha gansow henna'm tremennas 35 a-dreus an avon, rag gwelwel 36 an brassa varyans a'n me'y fres.
37 Ha hynwys esa'm, kepar ha'n wra, 38 yn subit, traow a wra'n divertya 39 pub traow aral dre verwonder.
40 Benen unnik a veu esa'm 41 ow kanna ha dybbia flur a flur 42 ow peynti hy fordh oll.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 «Deh, bella donna, che a’ raggi d’amore 44 ti scaldi, s’i’ vo’ credere a’ sembianti 45 che soglion esser testimon del core,
46 vegnati in voglia di trarreti avanti», 47 diss’ io a lei, «verso questa rivera, 48 tanto ch’io possa intender che tu canti.
query.result:
**English:**
43 “Ah, beautiful lady, who in the rays of love 44 warm yourself, if I am to believe the outward signs 45 that are usually the testimony of the heart,
46 let it please you to come forward,” 47 I said to her, “towards this bank, 48 so that I may understand what you are singing.
**Cornish:**
43 “Agh, benen vrassa, pyth a-ughas karanteth 44 ow tommhas, mar kyfsa kredis an semlantys 45 a wra soel testimony a'n colon,
46 whelas anken dhe vos dhe dhrehedhy anedha,” 47 medhes dhe'vy, “tu-ha an avon ma, 48 dhe bythav y'm boesel komprehendes pyth ow kanna.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Tu mi fai rimembrar dove e qual era 50 Proserpina nel tempo che perdette 51 la madre lei, ed ella primavera».
query.result:
**English:**
49 You make me remember where and what Proserpina was like 50 at the time when she lost 51 her mother, and she the springtime.
**Cornish:**
49 Thy wra'm gorra kovsow le may ha pyth o Proserpina 50 yn termyn pan golledhi 51 hy mamm, ha hitho an gwenton.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Come si volge, con le piante strette 53 a terra e intra sé, donna che balli, 54 e piede innanzi piede a pena mette,
55 volsesi in su i vermigli e in su i gialli 56 fioretti verso me, non altrimenti 57 che vergine che li occhi onesti avvalli;
58 e fece i prieghi miei esser contenti, 59 sì appressando sé, che ’l dolce suono 60 veniva a me co’ suoi intendimenti.
query.result:
**English:**
52 As a lady who dances turns, with her feet held close 53 to the ground and within herself, 54 and scarcely moves one foot in front of the other,
55 she turned towards me on the crimson and yellow 56 flowers, no differently 57 than a virgin who lowers her modest eyes;
58 and she made my requests be granted, 59 approaching me so that the sweet sound 60 came to me with its meanings.
**Cornish:**
52 Kepar ha benen ow dansya ow trehedhes, gans hy threis 53 streys dhe-ves an nor ha yntern hy honan, 54 ha skas henna ow pos dhe'y threis war-lergh,
55 hi a drehedhes war-tu dhe'n bleujyn ha melyn 56 fluryow tu-ha'n, marnas mar, 57 ages vyrgin ow leha hy lagha onest;
58 ha hi a wrug hemma'm bewi dhe vos kowlwrys, 59 ow tos dhe'm, marnas an dowr dowlys 60 a dheuth dhe'm gans hy intendymentys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Tosto che fu là dove l’erbe sono 62 bagnate già da l’onde del bel fiume, 63 di levar li occhi suoi mi fece dono.
query.result:
**English:**
61 As soon as she was there where the grasses are 62 already bathed by the waves of the beautiful river, 63 she granted me the gift of raising her eyes.
**Cornish:**
61 Kyns ages hi o ena le may an glesow 62 ow teves gans dowrow an avon vrassa, 63 hi a wrug hemma'm an goweth dhe dhrehedhy hy lagha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Non credo che splendesse tanto lume 65 sotto le ciglia a Venere, trafitta 66 dal figlio fuor di tutto suo costume.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I do not believe that so much light shone 65 beneath the eyelashes of Venus, pierced 66 by her son, beyond all his usual custom.
**Cornish:**
64 Nyns kredis vyth ow splannas kemmys lewth 65 a-woles lagha Venus, tryghys 66 gans hy mab a-ves yntern hy arver usadow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Ella ridea da l’altra riva dritta, 68 trattando più color con le sue mani, 69 che l’alta terra sanza seme gitta.
query.result:
**English:**
67 She was laughing from the other bank, directly opposite, 68 handling more colors with her hands 69 than the fertile earth produces without seed.
**Cornish:**
67 Hi o veu ow hwitha a'n avon aral dhe-ves, 68 ow treylya moy kala gans hy dhew, 69 ages an nor ughel heb had.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Tre passi ci facea il fiume lontani; 71 ma Elesponto, là ’ve passò Serse, 72 ancora freno a tutti orgogli umani,
73 più odio da Leandro non sofferse 74 per mareggiare intra Sesto e Abido, 75 che quel da me perch’ allor non s’aperse.
query.result:
**English:**
70 The river kept us three paces apart; 71 but the Hellespont, where Xerxes crossed, 72 still a bridle to all human pride,
73 did not suffer more hatred from Leander 74 for sailing between Sestos and Abydos, 75 than that river did from me because it did not open up then.
**Cornish:**
70 An avon o wrug hemma tri pas a-bell, 71 mes an Hellespont, le may Xerxes a drehedhes, 72 ethommo breydh dhe pub orgowl dhynvro,
73 nyns soffaras moy kas a Leandro 74 rag morhegi yntern Sestos ha Abidus, 75 ages an avon ma ow tos hemma pan nyns o agoras.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 «Voi siete nuovi, e forse perch’ io rido», 77 cominciò ella, «in questo luogo eletto 78 a l’umana natura per suo nido,
79 maravigliando tienvi alcun sospetto; 80 ma luce rende il salmo Delectasti, 81 che puote disnebbiar vostro intelletto.
query.result:
**English:**
76 “You are new here, and perhaps because I am laughing,” 77 she began, “in this place chosen 78 for human nature as its nest,
79 some suspicion holds you in wonder; 80 but the psalm Delectasti sheds light, 81 which can dispel the fog from your intellect.
**Cornish:**
76 “Why ow nowyth, ha mos rag owth ow hwitha,” 77 hi a dhallethas, “yn an le ma etholys, 78 dhe'n natur dhynvro rag hy nyth,
79 owth ow teves marghasow yn-mesk, 80 mes lewth ow teves an salm Delectasti, 81 a yll dysnebbia hy skogh a'gan intellekt.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 E tu che se’ dinanzi e mi pregasti, 83 dì s’altro vuoli udir; ch’i’ venni presta 84 ad ogne tua question tanto che basti».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And you who are in front and asked me, 83 say if you want to hear anything else; for I came quickly 84 to answer all your questions, as much as is enough.
**Cornish:**
82 Ha tŷ owth ow se’ a-rag hag owth ow pygas, 83 leverel mar owth ow kar dhe glywes traow aral; rag owth ow dheuth prest 84 dhe pub dhew goslow bys vyth marnas owth ow boes.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 «L’acqua», diss’ io, «e ’l suon de la foresta 86 impugnan dentro a me novella fede 87 di cosa ch’io udi’ contraria a questa».
query.result: **English:**85“The water,” I said, “and the sound of the forest86inspire within me a new faith87in something that I heard contrary to this.”**Cornish:**85“An dowr,” meuris, “hag an son a’n gwydh,86a wra dhemedhans onan fydh nowydh87a-dro dhe wharnav dhegys yn-dann.”

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Ond’ ella: «Io dicerò come procede 89 per sua cagion ciò ch’ammirar ti face, 90 e purgherò la nebbia che ti fiede.
query.result: **English:**88And she said: “I will tell you how it happens89that what amazes you proceeds from its cause,90and I will dispel the fog that strikes you.”**Cornish:**88Hag hynwys hi: “Me a leverel fatel89peryth a-rag ythoth a wra dhemedhans,90hag ythoth a wra’n keth a wra dhemedhans.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Lo sommo Ben, che solo esso a sé piace, 92 fé l’uom buono e a bene, e questo loco 93 diede per arr’ a lui d’etterna pace.
query.result: **English:**91The supreme Good, which alone pleases itself,92made man good and for good, and this place93he gave to him as a pledge of eternal peace.**Cornish:**91An Gwella Bras, neb onan hepkor a wra dhemedhans,92a wrug an den da, ha dhe vad, hag an le ma93a roos dhodho dhe vad rag termyn bys vyth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Per sua difalta qui dimorò poco; 95 per sua difalta in pianto e in affanno 96 cambiò onesto riso e dolce gioco.
query.result: **English:**94Through his own fault he dwelt here but a short time;95through his own fault he changed honorable laughter and sweet play96into weeping and distress.**Cornish:**94A-rag ythoth ef a veu bys vyth ama.95A-rag ythoth ef a dhemedhys canow ha poen96a dhemedhys ones lavar ha jowek dowr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Perché ’l turbar che sotto da sé fanno 98 l’essalazion de l’acqua e de la terra, 99 che quanto posson dietro al calor vanno,
100 a l’uomo non facesse alcuna guerra, 101 questo monte salìo verso ’l ciel tanto, 102 e libero n’è d’indi ove si serra.
query.result: **English:**97So that the disturbance that the exhalations of the water and the earth make below it,98which follow the heat as much as they can,99would not make war on man,100this mountain rose toward heaven so high,102and is free from them there where it is enclosed.**Cornish:**97Rag na wra’n an keth a wra dhemedhans a-wals98an essalasyon a’n dowr ha’n tir,99a wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans wosa dhe’n tommder,100na wra dhemedhans bresel dhe’n den,101an menydh ma a sevel dhe’n nef a-ugh,102ha lir yw dhyworth le may hy a wra dhemedhans keth.

**English:**103Now because the air turns completely in a circle104with the first revolution,105if its circle is not broken by some obstacle,106at this height, which is completely dissolved107in the living air, such motion strikes it,108and makes the forest rustle because it is dense;109and the smitten plant can do so much110that it impregnates the air with its virtue,111and that air, turning, shakes all around;112and the other earth, according to how it is worthy113in itself and because of its sky, conceives and bears114different woods of different virtues.**Cornish:**103Mes rag yn keth poynt oll an ebron104an ebron a wra dhemedhans gans an kynsa tro,105mar nas vo dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans torrys gans unn keth,106yn an ughelder ma a wra dhemedhans oll dhegredys107yn an ebron byw, keth poynt a wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans,108ha wra dhemedhans an gwydh a-rag ythoth ef a wra dhemedhans tewl;109ha’n plans torrys a wra dhemedhans gallos keth poynt,110na wra dhemedhans ythoth an ebron a-ugh gans ythoth ef,111hag henna, ow tros, a wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans a-dro dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans;112hag an tir aral, a-ugh ythoth ef a wra dhemedhans deg,113a-dro dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans ha’y nef, a wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans ha wra dhemedhans prennow dyffrans a-dro dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans dyffrans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Non parrebbe di là poi maraviglia, 116 udito questo, quando alcuna pianta 117 sanza seme palese vi s’appiglia.
query.result: **English:**115It would not seem a marvel to you then,116having heard this, when some plant117takes root there without visible seed.**Cornish:**115Na wra dhemedhans gallos marghus dhyworth ena,116wosa dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans klevys, pan vo unn plans117a wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans dhemedhys heb hadher a wra dhemedhans dhemedhys ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 E saper dei che la campagna santa 119 dove tu se’, d’ogne semenza è piena, 120 e frutto ha in sé che di là non si schianta.
query.result: **English:**118And you should know that the holy plain119where you are is full of every seed,120and it has fruit in it that is not uprooted there.**Cornish:**118Ha dhemedhys dyllo dhe’n keth a wra dhemedhans plas sans,119le may tys, a wra dhemedhans oll hadher a wra dhemedhans,120ha frooth a wra dhemedhans ythoth ef na wra dhemedhans a wra dhemedhans torrys ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Da questa parte con virtù discende 128 che toglie altrui memoria del peccato; 129 da l’altra d’ogne ben fatto la rende.
query.result:
**English:**
127 From this side with virtue descends 128 that which takes away from others the memory of sin; 129 from the other it renders every good deed.**Cornish:**
127 A-dhyworthma, gans vyrth, yth tyn 128 aga thynna an kov a-berth pechodh; 129 a-dhyworth an aral, pub tra dha ober da.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Quinci Letè; così da l’altro lato 131 Eünoè si chiama, e non adopra 132 se quinci e quindi pria non è gustato:
133 a tutti altri sapori esto è di sopra.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Here Lethe; thus on the other side 131 Eunoe is called, and it does not work 132 unless first tasted from here and there:
133 to all other flavors this is superior.**Cornish:**
130 Ama Letè; hemma war an aral latha 131 Eünoè y galwir, ha na wra ober 132 mar nas provir a-dhyworthma ha-dhyworth:
133 dhe pub sawr aral, hemma yw an wella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
134 E avvegna ch’assai possa esser sazia 135 la sete tua perch’ io più non ti scuopra,
136 darotti un corollario ancor per grazia; 137 né credo che ’l mio dir ti sia men caro, 138 se oltre promession teco si spazia.
query.result:
**English:**
134 And although your thirst may be largely satisfied 135 so that I do not reveal more to you,
136 I will give you one more corollary as a favor; 137 and I do not believe that my speech will be less dear to you, 138 if it ranges beyond the promise with you.**Cornish:**
134 Ha goslow soweth agan sawr 135 rag orth ythoma moy dhe dhiskudhys vy dhebmyn,
136 yth rof vy corollario aral rag gras; 137 ha na grysaf vy lavar bos moy dheera, 138 mar ythoma moy dhe dhiskudhys vy dhebmyn,
139 mar ythoma moy dhe dhiskudhys vy dhebmyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Quelli ch’anticamente poetaro 140 l’età de l’oro e suo stato felice, 141 forse in Parnaso esto loco sognaro.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Those who in ancient times were poets 140 of the golden age and its happy state, 141 perhaps dreamed of this place on Parnassus.**Cornish:**
139 An re beudh bardh koth, 140 oos oos an oes aour ha’y stad hylif, 141 marteuth y’n Parnasos an le ma sognas.
